wikipedia_page.main: Len Wincott (1907 – January 1983) was an English sailor, mutineer and communist activist who later defected to the Soviet Union.

response: Len Wincott, a leader of the mutiny, defected to the USSR in 1934. During World War II he survived the Siege of Leningrad but in 1946 he was sent to the Gulag after being accused of being a British spy; he was imprisoned for more than a decade. After his release in the 1950s, he became a friend of Donald MacLean in Moscow.Cecil, pp 20 & 178 Another leader, Navy boxer Fred Copeman, commanded the British Battalion of the International Brigades in the Spanish Civil War.Gurney, p 112

The mutiny lasted two days (15–16 September 1931). Copeman, with another able seaman – Len Wincott –  became a member of the Norfolk's strike committee. Although the mutiny was entirely peaceful, the Royal Navy imprisoned dozens of the ringleaders and dismissed hundreds more, Copeman among them. In Crusade in Spain, Jason Gurney notes that Copeman was not charged, suggesting that his role must have been far more minor than the leader he presented himself to have been.Crusade in Spain, p 70 Alan Ereira says that Copeman was one of the eight ringleaders "hustled outside the dockyard gates with 13 s[hillings]Thirteen shillings (65p) and a railway warrant".The Invergordon Mutiny, pp 165–166 According to Ereira, "Some of the men were seen crying outside the dockyard at Devonport. They were reduced to beggary."
* Len Wincott (1907–1983), English sailor, mutineer and communist activist who defected to the Soviet Union
